I. 

THE PROPOSAL 

 
1. 
I  submit  for  your  approval  the  following  report  and  recommendation  on  (i)  a  proposed 
programmatic  approach,  (ii)  a  proposed  policy-based  loan  (PBL)  for  subprogram  1,  and  (iii)  a 
proposed project loan to the Kingdom of Cambodia for the Second Decentralized Public Service 
and Financial Management Sector Development Program. 
 
2. 
The proposed sector development program (SDP) combines a  PBL with an investment 
component to support key reforms in public financial management (PFM) and decentralization. 
The PBL adopts a programmatic approach to strengthen subnational fiscal planning, PFM, and 
public administration. This enables the sequencing of reforms and phased support from the Asian 
Development  Bank  (ADB)  to  improve  service  delivery  and  bridge  the  urban–rural  divide.  The 
programmatic approach builds on ADB’s ongoing first Decentralized Public Service and Financial 
Management  Sector  Development  Program.1  The  project  component  will  operationalize  the 
National School of Local Administration (NASLA) to provide sustainable capacity development for 
staff of subnational administrations (SNAs).2   
 

II. 

THE SECTOR DEVELOPMENT PROGRAM 

Background and Development Constraints 

 
A. 
 
3. 
Economic performance. Cambodia has enjoyed strong economic growth between 1995 
and 2018; its gross domestic product (GDP) grew at an average annual rate of 7.7%. Growth has 
been  underpinned  with  effective  macroeconomic  management,  prudent  fiscal  policy,  strong 
performance in domestic revenue mobilization, and low risk of sovereign debt distress.3 Prior to 
the coronavirus disease (COVID-19), the poverty incidence declined from 47.8% in 2007 to 13.5% 
in 2014. These gains are under threat as the economy is now projected to contract by 5.5% in 
2020 due to COVID-19, pushing an additional 1.3 million into either moderate or extreme poverty. 
The government’s fiscal balance will worsen from -5.9% of GDP to -12.8%. Government revenues 
are expected to decline by 30.9% in 2020 as key sectors of the economy grind to a halt.4  
 
4. 
Development problem. Service delivery indicators have improved with progress made in 
providing roads, water supply, and sanitation; but access to basic services varies greatly. In 2017, 
only 77% of urban residents and 11% of rural residents had piped water supply. More than 75% 
of  urban  residents  did  not  have  regular  solid  waste  management  services.  Urbanization  has 
heightened  the  demand  for  services,  which  are  limited  by  ineffective  institutional  coordination. 
Provincial differences also highlight gender disparities—the proportion of women who have never 
attended formal education is higher in rural areas (17.5%) than in urban areas (10.8%).5 
 
5. 
Impact  of  COVID-19.  The  COVID-19  pandemic  has  led  to  a  significant  decline  in  key 
sectors of Cambodia’s economy and losses in livelihoods, with the unemployment rate increasing 
from 0.7% to 4.4% (footnote 4). Prior to the onset of COVID-19, more than 70% of Cambodians 
already  lived  on  less  than  $3  a  day,  vulnerable  to  economic  and  external  shocks.  Poor  and 
vulnerable households are especially at risk from the impact of COVID-19. The government will

6. 
Weak  subnational  planning.  The  government  embarked  on  decentralization  and 
deconcentration  (D&D)  reforms  in  2001,  establishing  a  comprehensive  subnational  legislative 
framework  which  defined  SNAs  as  the  legal  entities  responsible  for  service  delivery, 
responsiveness, and accountability.7 Progress made on service delivery outcomes across SNA 
tiers has been mixed with functions and the assignment of key responsibilities unclear. Provinces 
which  are  larger,  better  funded  and  have  more  capacity  are  able  to  deliver  services  more 
effectively  than  districts  which  are  underdeveloped,  underfunded  and  have  greater  capacity 
needs.  The  lack  of  complaints  and  dispute  resolution  mechanisms  to  hold  service  providers 
accountable for services provided to citizens also limits overall coverage and quality of services.   
 
7. 
Ineffective  revenue  and  expenditure  management.  Revenue  mobilization  increased 
from  15.2%  of  GDP  in  2014  to  25.9%  in  2019  with  improvements  in  tax  administration  and 
efficiency,8  but  remains  centralized.9  Availability  of  resources  to  meet  mandates  for  service 
delivery  remains  low.  Between  2012  and  2018,  district–municipality–khan  (DMK)  funding  as  a 
share of the total SNA spending increased from 6.4% to 9.2%.10 The share of commune–sangkat 
funding marginally declined from 27.9% to 25.8%, reflecting priority to the DMK tiers for service 
delivery.  Fiscal  transfers  from  the  national  budget  to  the  capital  and  provinces  accounted  for 
64.9%  of  total  SNA  spending.  Strengthening  domestic  revenue mobilization  at  the  subnational 
level will be key to service provision and meeting the Sustainable Development Goals.11 
 
8. 
Weak  public  administration  and  poorly  skilled  subnational  officials.  Skills 
development of SNA staff is hampered by the absence of a common institutional framework that 
aligns  with  their  duties  of  service  delivery.  SNA  staff  lack  regulatory  knowledge  and  technical 
skills.12  Women  hold  only  18%  of  permanent  positions  in  the  civil  service.  Existing  institutions 
such  as  the  Royal  School  of  Administration  serve  a  narrow  cohort  of  civil  servants  and  are 
operating at full capacity.13 The investment component underpins the overall reform program by 
addressing this skills shortage that constrains effective service delivery at the subnational level.

 Sector Development Program Description 

Lessons  learned.  Important  lessons  have  emerged  from  ADB’s  engagement  in  D&D 
11. 
reforms in Cambodia. First, the political, fiscal, and administrative complexities in D&D reforms 
require flexibility in meeting emerging needs and realistic timeframes for implementation. Building 
consensus amongst diverse stakeholders requires significant efforts to maintain momentum for 
reforms.  Second,  while  integration  of  policy-based  and  project  interventions  can  leverage 
commitment  for  long  term  policy  reforms,  more  support  on  implementation  is  needed.25  The 
proposed SDP reinforces the D&D policy and regulatory framework, while recognizing the need 
for long term support to SNAs for successful implementation of D&D policies.   
 
12. 
ADB value addition. ADB’s long-term and comprehensive engagement in Cambodia has 
supported  legal,  policy,  and  institutional  reforms  key  to  furthering  D&D  reforms.  ADB  has 
previously  provided  TA  to  support  functional  mapping  of  SNA  responsibilities  and  the  legal 
framework for intergovernmental fiscal relations.26 ADB also provided TA to pilot decentralization 
of key services such as rural water supply to districts.27 ADB TA resources have supported needs 
analysis for SNA staff and advisory support for the governance structure of NASLA and delivered 
five pilot courses, including a leadership course for women.28 The project under DPSFM II will 
ensure  sustainable  capacity  building  and  innovations  that  add  value  by:  (i)  ensuring  teaching 
quality  through  peer-to-peer  links;  (ii) optimizing  information  technology  solutions  to  improve 
teacher training and student learning; and (iii) tailoring the NASLA curriculum to SNA staff needs. 
 
C. 
 
13. 
The  overall  program  is  aligned  with  the  following  impact:  SNAs  deliver  public  services 
sustainably,  effectively,  and  efficiently  to  all  Cambodians.  The  overall  program  will  have  the 
following outcome: service delivery by SNAs strengthened.29 The first subprogram will develop 
the legislative framework for stronger SNA governance underpinned by an investment component 
for the skills development of SNA staff. The second subprogram will support implementation of 
better service delivery, rendered more important due to the constraints on revenue mobilization 
and expenditures as a result of the COVID-19 pandemic. The project loan will help meet the core 
capacity building needs associated with the overall program.  
 
14. 
Reform area 1: Vertical and horizontal coordination for responsive and accountable 
service  delivery  strengthened.  The  government  improved  the  links  between  national  and 
subnational policy objectives of strengthened service delivery. First, it approved the Subnational 
Budget  Reform  Strategy  2019–2025  to  outline  the  next  generation  of  budget  reforms.  This 
included the expansion of program budgeting and inclusion of SNAs to ensure that local priorities 
are  integrated  with  national  objectives.  Second,  to  improve  efficiency  and  coordination,  the 
government approved a sub-decree that integrated district-level line ministry offices with district 
administrations. District administrations will have an expanded mandate for service delivery with 
additional  responsibilities  in  education,  rural  development,  and  social  affairs.  Third,  the 
government established internal control functions for improved risk management within the new 
unified district administrations. Fourth, the government approved a sub-decree to establish one-
window services for citizens for faster processing of business licenses and permits. Ombudsman

Reform  area  2:  Revenue  and  expenditure  management  to  meet  local  needs 
improved.  The  government  boosted  the  resources  available  to  SNAs  to  fulfill  their  service 
delivery duties. First, to meet the increasing development needs of communes and sangkats, the 
government approved the transfer of additional resources from the national budget.30 As a result, 
the overall resource envelope for commune and sangkats has increased with the development 
fund  component  more  than  doubled  in  2020  to  address  infrastructure  priorities  and  social 
services,  including  the  expansion  of  services  for  women  and  marginalized  groups.  Second,  to 
improve  the  management  of  subnational  assets,  the  Ministry  of  Economy  and  Finance  (MEF) 
submitted a law on the management and use of state property to the cabinet for approval. The 
proposed law will ensure the transparent management of subnational assets—(i) management of 
state property; (ii) permissible arrangements for rent, sale, and concession of state property; and 
(iii) responsibility for revenue and tax liabilities. Finally, the government approved a 15% share of 
nontax revenues (previously 0%) collected by line ministries and shared with SNAs, to boost their 
revenue base and fund service delivery responsibilities. Under subprogram 2, financial guidelines 
will  be  established  to  improve  commune,  or  sangkat  fund  management  and  nontax  revenue-
sharing arrangements collected from state property strengthened. 
 
16. 
Reform  area  3:  Public  administration  skills  and  competencies  of  subnational 
officials enhanced. The government addressed longer-term capacity development needs. First, 
the government approved a sub-decree and guidelines to give SNAs more autonomy in managing 
staff.  Second, the Ministry of Interior (MOI) endorsed prakas and a strategic plan for long-term 
capacity development including delivery of key training programs by type and target group, and 
milestones for improving the development of human resources. Third, under the interim NASLA 
training  strategy  supported  by  ADB,  five  courses  were  successfully  designed  and  piloted  to 
2,087 SNA staff, of which 20% were women. A leadership course for women at the subnational 
level was piloted and jointly delivered with the Ministry of Women’s Affairs. Finally, the National 
Committee  for  Sub-National  Democratic  Development  (NCDD)  approved  its  gender  equality 
policy  to  strengthen  the  role  and  participation  of  women  in  service  delivery.  This  included:  
(i) greater representation of women in management; (ii) allocation of resources; and (iii) improved 
services for women and children. Under subprogram 2, guidelines will be adopted to strengthen 
SNAs’  performance  management.  NASLA  will  deliver  a  tailored  curriculum  and  implement  the 
gender equality policy at the subnational level. 
 
17.

GLOSSARY 
Khans  are  part  of  the  middle  tier  of  local  government  comprising  districts,
municipalities,  and  khans.  Khans  are  only  located  within  the  capital,
Phnom Penh.
Prakas is a ministerial or inter-ministerial decision aligned with a law or sub-
decree to which it refers and used to implement and clarify specific provisions
in the higher-level legislative documents.
A sub-decree is an executive regulation prepared by the ministries, adopted
by the Council of Ministers, and endorsed by the Prime Minister. It clarifies
provisions in a law by describing the functions of government institutions and
may appoint senior government officials in key roles and responsibilities.
There are three tiers of local government in Cambodia that are collectively
referred to as subnational administrations. The highest tier is the capital and
provincial  tier  and  includes  the  capital  (Phnom  Penh)  and  provinces.  The
middle tier of local government are districts, municipalities and  khans. The
lowest tier are communes and sangkats.
